user.biography: Jesus, Ben, Helen + Mae, small towns, old houses, old cars & our little store @laurelmercantile

node.text: As of October 2020, about 164,000 small businesses have closed and 60% will never reopen. This year, more than ever, shopping small MATTERS. A SPECIAL new episode of Home Town all about local love for Laurel and Wetumpka airs tonight at 8/7 c! Y’all don’t miss it!#SmallTogether

node.title: Without small businesses, towns like Laurel die.

node.text: Found our old wedding video and got a little teary. 12 years ago today. Still so thankful to be your wife, @scotsman.co. (watch for @malraz and @jobforjim — they got engaged that night!) music: lloyd, i’m ready to be heartbroken by @cameraobscuraband and by your side by blue mountain

node.text: I’ve not picked up my guitar in so long, but Helen loves this one and it would do y’all good to know it too. I’m rusty, forgetting chords, but it still feels good to sing a song.

node.title: Something to Love (cover) by @jasonisbell and the 400 unit

node.text:
cs lewis gave me enormous comfort today, with words from 1948. whether a bomb or a virus: 

“In one way we think a great deal too much of the atomic bomb. ‘How are we to live in an atomic age?’ I am tempted to reply: ‘Why, as you would have lived in the sixteenth century when the plague visited London almost every year, or as you would have lived in a Viking age when raiders from Scandinavia might land and cut your throat any night; or indeed, as you are already living in an age of cancer, an age of syphilis, an age of paralysis, an age of air raids, an age of railway accidents, an age of motor accidents.’

In other words, do not let us begin by exaggerating the novelty of our situation. Believe me, dear sir or madam, you and all whom you love were already sentenced to death before the atomic bomb was invented: and quite a high percentage of us were going to die in unpleasant ways. We had, indeed, one very great advantage over our ancestors—anesthetics; but we have that still. It is perfectly ridiculous to go about whimpering and drawing long faces because the scientists have added one more chance of painful and premature death to a world which already bristled with such chances and in which death itself was not a chance at all, but a certainty.

This is the first point to be made: and the first action to be taken is to pull ourselves together. If we are all going to be destroyed by an atomic bomb, let that bomb when it comes find us doing sensible and human things—praying, working, teaching, reading, listening to music, bathing the children, playing tennis, chatting to our friends over a pint and a game of darts—not huddled together like frightened sheep and thinking about bombs. They may break our bodies (a microbe can do that) but they need not dominate our minds.” - cs lewis

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Erin Napier on August 15, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text: I am struggling with this puzzle for ages 6+ but my 3 year old keeps telling me “don’t say you’re bad at puzzles mama. you’re getting better.” 🥺 (but i really am so bad at puzzles while she can finish one in 15 minutes)

We can FINALLY tell you officially, #HGTVHomeTown season 6 and #BensWorkshop season 2 are in production and coming in 2022.
I am so proud of you, @scotsman.co!

node.text: at a little over 2 months old, mae makes cooing / puppy sounds, eats 5 oz. per feeding, sleeps from 9 pm - 7:30 am and has a nap schedule. i can’t believe we are almost out of the newborn days. #maedays

node.text: all dogs go to heaven ❤️ we (and especially she) will miss baker. thankful for the 12 years he lived.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Erin Napier on July 23, 2021 tagging @laurelmercantile. May be an image of 1 person and indoor.

node.text: As more of you are finding your way to our corner of the internet, you’re discovering our two stores: @laurelmercantile and @scotsmangeneralstore. Someone on twitter told me they were disappointed with our prices, and I’d like to share why our goods are priced the way they are. Laurel, like many towns, was built on manufacturing. We believe that if we are going to be serious about revitalizing America’s hometowns, then we have to be serious about supporting American manufacturing and the small towns that depend on it. We believe that American makers deserve fair pay for quality work. And even though it means our profit margin is smaller, we’ve built our retail company around this question: “Is there a reputable American manufacturer of this product?” If we are unable to find suitable American sources to satisfy customer demand, we either skip those products, make sure a component is USA Made, or find expert manufacturers from countries with ethical and sustainable business practices. If none of that works, we make it ourselves at Scotsman Co. When we buy things that are made in the USA, we make our small towns stronger. So when you ask why we don’t sell cheaper imported goods, ask yourself: what is the real cost of a bargain? Read all about it at the link in my profile! 🇺🇸
